metadata.framework: Miyai et al. (2025) Jr. AI Scientist Risk Assessment

risk_assessment.recommendation: REVISION SUGGESTED. Add more verified data sources or acknowledge limitations.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Colombia's fiscal sustainability improved over time (declining implementation gap)
hypotheses.baseline_source: Dixon & Landau (2025) predict transformative success with adequate support. Implementation gap is proxy for fiscal sustainability.
hypotheses.theoretical_basis: Transformative constitutions with popular support (SP > 0.65) and open pathways (CLI < 0.5) should show NARROWING gap as implementation proceeds. Colombia 1991 had both conditions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Chile 2022 would have had massive fiscal gap if passed (utopian)
hypotheses.baseline_source: Dixon & Landau (2025) predict utopian failure without adequate resources. Fiscal gap = lack of resources.
hypotheses.theoretical_basis: Constitutions with blocked pathways (CLI > 0.65) and insufficient support (SP < 0.35) show LARGE gaps between promises and capacity. Chile 2022 had both conditions.

hypotheses.hypothesis_text: Argentina shows fossilization: worsening fiscal gap over 76 years
hypotheses.baseline_source: Extended Phenotype Theory predicts lock-in accumulation. Argentina Art. 14bis persists since 1949.
hypotheses.theoretical_basis: Utopian constitutions that cannot be reformed (CLI growing) accumulate WIDENING gaps as promises persist but implementation capacity declines. Argentina CLI grew +0.0055/year.

claims.claim_text: Colombia data loaded: 8 time points from 1991-2025
claims.source: ../DATA/analysis_results/colombia_constitutional_fitness.csv (generated from colombia_h1_analysis.py with World Bank + DANE sources)

claims.claim_text: Argentina data loaded: 9 time points from 1949-2025
Chile data loaded: 1 projection for 2022 (counterfactual if passed)
Colombia FSI improved from 65.0% (1991) to 88.0% (2025), gaining 23.0 percentage points
claims.source: FSI = (1 - Gap) × 100%, where Gap from colombia_constitutional_fitness.csv
claims.theoretical_justification: Improvement expected per H1: transformative success with adequate support should narrow gap
claims.external_validation: Consistent with World Bank data showing Colombia social spending increase 8% → 15% GDP

claims.claim_text: Argentina FSI declined from 32.0% (1990) to 23.0% (2025), losing 9.0 percentage points
claims.source: FSI = (1 - Gap) × 100%, where Gap from argentina_cf_trajectory.csv
claims.theoretical_justification: Decline expected per H3: fossilization with growing CLI should widen gap
claims.external_validation: Consistent with Argentina informality rate increasing 35% → 45% and failed reform attempts (0/23 success)

claims.claim_text: Chile 2022 projected FSI: 22.8% (if constitution had passed)
claims.source: FSI = (1 - Gap) × 100%, where Gap = 0.7724 from chile_h2_analysis.py fiscal gap calculation
claims.theoretical_justification: Low FSI expected per H2: utopian failure with insufficient resources
claims.external_validation: Validated by actual outcome: 62% rejection (voters perceived unviability)
limitations: Based on 2022 fiscal space estimates (2.5% GDP available vs 13.5% GDP promised)
Does not account for potential budget adjustments

claims.claim_text: Colombia 2025 FSI is 65.2 percentage points higher than Chile 2022 projected FSI
claims.theoretical_justification: Large difference validates Dixon & Landau: transformative (Colombia) vs utopian (Chile)

claims.claim_text: Chile 2022 and Argentina 2025 converge at ~23% FSI (difference only 0.2 points)
claims.theoretical_justification: Convergence expected: both systems fiscally unsustainable (Chile would be, Argentina is)
claims.external_validation: Both at <50% viability threshold, confirming utopian territory
